title: Family who keep pet wolf at home and he’s very well behaved
text:
The family say they have trained Seryi to turn on light switches and open windows (Picture: Astrakhan 2015)

A family in Russia decided to welcome a pet wolf into their home and for the first time are sharing their story of what it’s like to live with him.

Ivan Lebedev and his daughter Alexandra, from Volgograd, Russia, welcomed Seryi into their lives in May 2017.

They have spent two and a half years living with Seryi in their apartment, after picking him up when he was less than a month old.

He was found by farmers in a wolves’ lair in the Astrakhan region of the country.

Ivan couldn’t resist buying the cub and says he’s even trained Seryi to turn on light switches and open windows.

Mr Lebedev said: ‘I think the main difficulty for me right now with handling him is the walks.

Seryi devours over a kilo of meat a day (Picture: Astrakhan 2015)

‘He needs two really long walks a day and you cannot try and fool him, so no matter how tired we are we have to take him out.’

‘Also, being a wild animal, he also eats a huge amount of food – around 1.2kg of meat a day.’

Although the family already lives with two hunting dogs, they say having a pet wolf brings new challenges.

Ivan Lebedev couldn’t resist buying the pet (Picture: Astrakhan 2015)

Ivan’s daughter Alexandra welcomed Seryi into family home in May 2017 (Picture: Astrakhan 2015)

Mr Lebedev said: ‘Wolves are very different from dogs, where a dog will ask, a wolf will demand.

‘But you should not let him do whatever he wants, as he will feel like you are not strong enough to be a leader of the pack.

‘However, most of the time he just behaves like a normal big dog would.’

Ivan says he and Alexandra try to keep Seryi away from smaller dogs when he goes on walks, ‘just in case something bad happens’.

Despite the challenges, Mr Lebedev says he is happy Seryi is in his life, adding: ‘This wolf is a member of our family and all people who know our family love Seryi.’

description: The family have spent two and a half years living with the pet wolf.
